original_title: Strikes and Protests in Sri Lanka today (1); Multiple services affected
original_body_lines: COLOMBO (News 1st); The Professionals Trade Union Collective has planned to stage a series of strikes and protests on Wednesday (1).

One of the main demands by the PTCU is for the immediate withdrawal of the government's new tax regime, where an income tax bracket between 6% to 36% is imposed on monthly income of more than Rs. 100,000/-.
Trade Unions attached to Sri Lanka Railways, Health, Education, and Postal Services would not go on strike, however, they are expected to engage in protests island-wide.
The PTCU noted that more than 40 trade unions will engage in strikes or protests on March 1.
Trade Unions attached to Sri Lanka Railways said that it is possible that train services would be cancelled or delayed.
The Government Medical Officers Association noted that health services are likely to cripple on Wednesday (1) due to the trade union action.
On Tuesday (28) the GMOA said its members would also refrain from attending private practice.
The Federation of University Teachers Associations noted that all its members would go on strike on Wednesday (1).
The Ceylon Bank Employees Union said that employees from 18 private and state banks will take part in the strike action.
It added that trade unions at the Central Bank of Sri Lanka will also join the strike.
Trade Unions attached to the Ceylon Electricity Board including engineers would support the trade union action by reporting sick.

Trade Unions attached to the Sri Lanka Ports Authority, Ceylon Petroleum Corporation, Sri Lanka Telecom, Water Supply and other state services have also extended their support to the strike, and protests.
